item.label: Cerebral sulci
item.name: Cerebral sulci
item.description: A cerebral fissure is AKA a cerebral sulcus (sing.); sulci (pl.).  Fissures are the depressions or grooves between the gyri or convolutions of the cerebral cortex.  Fissure generally refers to a sulcus that is particularly deep.  The terms are used interchangeably in some cases.

item.label: Central sulcus
item.name: Central sulcus
item.description: The central sulcus (of Rolando) is an important sulcus on the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal from the parietal lobes. It extends from just medial to the superior border of the hemisphere downward to the lateral or Sylvian fissure. The primary motor and somatosensory areas of cortex form the gyri (pre-central and post-central, respectively) on either side of this sulcus.

item.label: Parieto-occipital sulcus
item.name: Parieto-occipital sulcus
item.description: The parieto-occipital sulcus is a deep fissure that divides the parietal from the occipital lobes on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere.

item.label: Commissures
item.name: Commissures
item.description: The term 'commissure' refers to bundles of axons that cross the midline of the neuraxis and connect corresponding areas of the brain. Significant commissures in the brain are the corpus callosum, anterior and posterior commissures.  In the spinal cord, the anterior or ventral white commissure is very important.

item.label: Corpus callosum
item.name: Corpus callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Rostrum
item.name: Rostrum
item.description: The rostrum of the corpus callosum is a thin band of nerve fibers beneath the genu containing commissural fibers interconnecting the orbital cortices.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu is the sharp bend in the corpus callosum at it most anterior or rostral aspect.  The commissural fibers within the genu interconnect the frontal lobes.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body
item.description: The body is the main portion of the corpus callosum containing commissural fibers which distribute extensively between the two hemispheres.

item.label: Splenium
item.name: Splenium
item.description: The splenium is the thick and rounded posterior aspect of the corpus callosum.  These commissural axons interconnect the occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Anterior commissure
item.name: Anterior commissure
item.description: The anterior commissure is a small and compact bundle of commissural axons located just beneath and caudal to the rostrum of the corpus callosum. It connects corresponding areas in the temporal cortices as well as olfactory structures.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Crus
item.name: Crus
item.description: The crus is that portion of the fornix between the fimbria and body of the fornix. It curves superiorly to just beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Column
item.name: Column
item.description: The columns of the fornix is the portion that leaves the body of the fornix to turn ventrally and then caudally toward the septal nuclei and mammillary bodies of the hypothalamus.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Anterior nucleus
item.name: Anterior nucleus
item.description: The anterior thalamic nucleus is the thalamic relay for the limbic system.  For example, the mammillothalamic tract extends from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. Grossly, it forms a small bump or tubercle on the surface of the thalamus that borders the interventricular foramen of Monro.

item.label: Medial dorsal nucleus
item.name: Medial dorsal nucleus
item.description: The dorsomedial nucleus of the thalamus (DM) is AKA the medial dorsal nucleus.  It is located medial to the internal medullary lamina of the thalamus.  It has important connections with the prefrontal association cortex and the limbic system.

item.label: Stria medullaris of thalamus
item.name: Stria medullaris
item.description: The stria medullaris of the thalamus is a thin fiber bundle that appears as a horizontal ridge on the dorsal and medial aspect of the thalamus.  It originates in the septal nuclei and terminates in the habenular nuclei. The roof of the third ventricle stretches between the stria medullaris of the thalamus on the two sides.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Mammillary body
item.name: Mammillary body
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Mammillothalamic tract
item.name: Mammillothalamic tract
item.description: The mammillothalamic tract is a bundle of fibers projecting from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. It is part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Epithalamus, Habenula
item.name: Epithalamus Habenula
item.description: The habenula is a small bump or mound on the dorsomedial surface of the caudal thalamus.  it is formed by the underlying habenular nuclei.  It is part of the epithalamus.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic nerve/chiasm
item.name: Visual pathway Optic
item.description: The Optic Nerve fibers (Cranial Nerve II) travel from the retina of each eye toward the brain.  There is a partial crossing of the nerve fibers in the Optic Chiasm.  Beyond the chiasm, the nerve fibers accumulate in the Optic Tract.  The Optic Tract then carries the visual information from the contralateral visual field to the Lateral Geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and beyond to the Visual Cortex.

item.label: Brainstem
item.name: Brainstem
item.description: The term brainstem (or brain stem) generally refers to the medulla, pons and midbrain. Some sources include parts of the diencephalon in this definition.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Superior colliculus
item.name: Superior colliculus
item.description: The superior colliculi are paired, rounded structures on the superior surface of the rostral midbrain formed by the laminated or layered nuclei of the superior colliculi. Along with the paired inferior colliculi in the caudal midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The superior colliculus receives input from the retina and visual cortex and sends its output to the pulvinar of the thalamus, and plays a role in controlling eye movements, etc..

item.label: Inferior colliculus
item.name: Inferior colliculus
item.description: The inferior colliculi are paired rounded structures on the superior surface of the caudal midbrain formed by the paired nuclei of the inferior colliculus.  Along with the paired superior colliculi in the rostral midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The inferior colliculus is an important synapse in the auditory pathway, receiving auditory input from the lateral lemniscus and sending its output via the brachium of the inferior colliculus to synapse in the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.

item.label: Periaqueductal gray
item.name: Periaqueductal gray
item.description: Periaqueductal gray matter is the area of gray matter surrounding the cerebral aqueduct of the midbrain. Some of the neurons in this area are part of a descending analgesic pathway that relays in the nucleus raphe magnus of the medulla and subsequently blocks pain at the level of the dorsal horn.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum is that portion of the midbrain that lies between the cerebral aqueduct and the crus cerebri.  It includes the major ascending sensory tracts (medial lemniscus, spinothalamic), the red nucleus and the substantia nigra.

item.label: Oculomotor nucleus
item.name: Oculomotor nucleus
item.description: This third or oculomotor cranial nerve nucleus is located in the midline of the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. It consists of lower motor neurons that innervate the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palpebrae muscles that move the eye. It also contains pre-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons in a part of the nuclear complex called the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. These parasympathetic fibers terminate in the ciliary ganglion; post-ganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion innervate the constrictors of the pupil and the ciliary muscles.

item.label: Oculomotor nerve
item.name: Oculomotor nerve
item.description: The third or oculomotor cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the ipsilateral medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palapebrae muscles that move the eye. It also includes parasympathetic fibers that terminate in the ipsilateral ciliary ganglion; post-ganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion innervate the constrictors of the pupil and the ciliary muscles.

item.label: Red nucleus
item.name: Red nucleus
item.description: The red nucleus is a large, round nucleus in the tegmentum of the midbrain that appears pink or red on freshly-sectioned tissue. It is involved with motor control via its connections with the cerebellum. It receives contralateral input from both the dentate and interposed deep cerebellar nuclei; its primary output in the human is to the ipsilateral inferior olivary nucleus via the central tegmental tract. Since the inferior olivary nucleus projects to contralateral cerebellum, the red nucleus is part of a feedback loop to the cerebellum. While the red nucleus gives origin to a significant rubrospinal tract in non-human species, this tract appears to be of limited extent and importance in humans.

item.label: Decussation Sup Cerebell Peduncle
item.name: Decussation of SCP
item.description: A major portion of the output from the cerebellum travels in the superior cerebellar peduncles.  As these paired peduncles travel rostrally toward the midbrain, they cross the midline within the tegmentum of the caudal midbrain in what is termed the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum_1
item.description: The tegmentum or tegmental pons forms the dorsal aspect of the pons.  It is continuous with the tegmental portions of both the midbrain and medulla. Includes cranial nerve nuclei and clinically important sensory tracts [medial lemniscal, spinothalamic, lateral lemniscal]. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on it dorsal surface.

item.label: Abducens nucleus
item.name: Abducens nucleus
item.description: The abducens nucleus contains the lower motor neurons of the abducens nerve that innervate the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. It also contains interneurons that project through the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to communicate with the contralateral medial rectus neurons in the oculomotor complex; these interneurons are instrumental for conjugate horizontal eye movements. The abducens nucleus is located close to the floor of the fourth ventricle beneath the elevation known as the facial colliculus. The facial motor nerve fibers that innervate the muscles of facial expression, travel over or superior to the abducens nucleus and beneath the facial colliculus.

item.label: Facial nerve fibers
item.name: Facial nerve fibers
item.description: The facial or seventh cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem in the cerebellopontine angle with the vestibulocochlear nerve. The most important sensory component carries taste from the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue; motor components innervate the skeletal muscles of facial expression, stapedius, etc. as well as provide the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar
item.description: The basilar pons is AKA the basal pons. It is the ventral portion of the pons that includes the following important elements that are primarily involved in motor control: corticospinal, corticobulbar, corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts plus the pontine nuclei. Thus, it serves as a conduit for descending motor pathways from cerebral cortex to the pons, medulla and spinal cord. In addition, it connects the cerebral cortex with the cerebellum via synapses of the corticopontine fibers on pontine nuclei that then give origin to the pontocerebellar fibers which terminate in cerebellum.

item.label: Pontine nuclei
item.name: Pontine nuclei
item.description: The pontine nuclei are a large number of small nuclei located in the basilar portion of the pons. They are scattered among many nerve fibers in this area. They receive input from the ipsilateral cerebral cortex via corticopontine fibers that travel to the pons via the internal capsule and cerebral crus; they give origin to pontocerebellar fibers whose axons cross the midline and enter the cerebellum contralateral to their origin

item.label: Corticospinal tract
item.name: Corticospinal tract
item.description: The corticospinal tract is a descending pathway (of Upper Motor Neurons) that originates in the cerebral cortex, travels through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, basis pedunculi of the midbrain, basilar pons, the pyramid of the medulla and then decussates at the medulla/spinal cord junction. Upon entering the spinal cord, the majority of the tract travels in the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord with its fibers terminating along the length of the cord on both motor and sensory neurons. Its fibers and their cells of origin are considered to be Upper Motor Neurons. This is the primary pathway that deals with skilled voluntary movements.

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Inferior olivary nucleus
item.name: Inferior olivary nucleus
item.description: The inferior olivary nucleus is a large, convoluted, drawstring purse-like nucleus in the anterolateral medulla.  It receives multiple afferents from the spinal cord, red nucleus, cerebellum, etc. It projects to the contralateral cerebellum via olivocerebellar fibers that travel in the contralateral inferior cerebellar peduncle to terminate as climbing fibers in the cerebellum. Can be confused with the dentate nucleus in the cerebellum because of its similar appearance.

item.label: Trigeminal spinal nucleus
item.name: Spinal trigeminal nucleus
item.description: The trigeminal spinal nucleus is AKA the spinal trigeminal nucleus. It is a portion of the trigeminal sensory nuclei that exists as a longitudinal column of cells within the lateral aspect of the caudal pons and medulla. Caudally, it merges with the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (particularly, the substantia gelatinosa); rostrally it merges into the trigeminal main sensory nucleus. It consists of second-order sensory neurons that receive primarily pain and temperature information from the head via input from the trigeminal spinal (or spinal trigeminal) tract. Efferents from this nucleus terminate in the contralateral ventral posterior medial nucleus of the thalamus.

item.label: Vestibular nuclei
item.name: Vestibular nuclei
item.description: The vestibular nuclei are a group of four sub-nuclei present bilaterally in the floor of the fourth ventricle at the junction of the pons and medulla. The four sub-nuclei are the inferior, lateral, medial and superior. These nuclei receive input from the vestibular organs (cristae of the semicircular ducts and maculae of the utricle and saccule of the inner ear) via the eighth cranial nerve. These nuclei project to the nuclei innervating the extraocular muscles via the medial longitudinal fasciculus, to the cerebellum, to the spinal cord, thalamus and reticular formation.

item.label: Solitary tract
item.name: Solitary tract
item.description: The solitary tract is located in the medulla and caudal pons, surrounded by the solitary nucleus, it consists of primary afferent or first order fibers carrying taste input via the facial, glossopharyngeal and possibly the vagal nerves to the rostral aspect of the solitary nucleus (SVA) and general visceral input via the glossopharyngeal and vagal nerves (GVA) to the caudal aspect of the solitary nucleus.

item.label: Solitary nucleus
item.name: Solitary nucleus
item.description: The solitary nucleus is a visceral sensory nucleus in the medulla & caudal pons located as a thin column of cells just lateral to the sulcus limitans in the floor of the fourth ventricle and surrounding the solitary tract. The rostral portion of the nucleus is AKA the gustatory nucleus since it receives primary afferent taste input via the facial, glossopharyngeal and possibly the vagal nerves; this part of the nucleus is considered special visceral afferent (SVA). The caudal portion of the nucleus receives primary general visceral afferent (GVA) input from the viscera, aortic and carotid barareceptors, etc over the glossopharyngeal and vagal nerves.

item.label: Cuneate fasciculus
item.name: Cuneate fasciculus
item.description: The cuneate fasciculus is the lateral portion of the dorsal or posterior column rostral to T6. It includes large, uncrossed, primary afferent fibers carrying tactile, vibratory and proprioceptive input from the upper extremity and the body above approximately T6; most of these fibers will terminate in the cuneate and lateral cuneate nuclei in the medulla.

item.label: Cuneate nucleus
item.name: Cuneate nucleus
item.description: The cuneate nucleus contains the second-order neurons that receive tactile, vibratory and proprioceptive input from the upper extremity and the body above T6 via the cuneate fasciculus of the spinal cord. The axons of these cuneate neurons decussate in the medulla to form the medial lemniscus which will travel to and synapse in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus of the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebellum, Vermis
item.name: Cerebellum, vermis
item.description: The vermis of the cerebellum is the most medial region, i.e. the narrow midline section associated with the anterior, posterior and flocculonodular lobes of the cerebellum.

item.label: Anterior lobe
item.name: Anterior lobe
item.description: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion of the cerebellum anterior to the primary fissure, including parts of the vermis and hemisphere.

item.label: Primary fissure
item.name: Primary fissure
item.description: The primary fissure of the cerebellum separates the anterior lobe from the posterior lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Posterior lobe
item.name: Posterior lobe
item.description: The posterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion between the primary and posterolateral fissures.  It includes parts of the vermis and hemispheres.

item.label: Posterolateral fissure
item.name: Posterolateral fissure
item.description: The posterolateral fissure of the cerebellum separates the posterior lobe from the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Nodule
item.name: Nodule
item.description: The nodule or nodulus of the cerebellum is a small portion of the ventral and anterior vermis that is attached to the flocculus to form the flocculonodular lobe. Functionally, the flocculonodular lobe is associated with balance as well as movements of the eyes.

item.label: Ventricular system
item.name: Ventricular system
item.description: The ventricular system is a series of interconnected cerebrospinal-filled chambers within the cerebral hemispheres. Cerebrospinal fluid is formed in the choroid plexus located in the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricle
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Fourth ventricle
item.name: Fourth ventricle
item.description: The fourth ventricle is a rhomboid-shaped space located superior to the pons and medulla. The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the inferior and superior medullary vela plus the cerebellum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the fourth ventricle from the third ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen of Magendie, located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, and the two lateral foramina of Luschka, located at the most lateral aspect of the fourth ventricle, i.e. in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, bilaterally.  The choroid plexus is located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, beneath the inferior medullary velum.  The choroid plexus extends outside of the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka, where it can be visualized in the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Superior medullary velum
item.name: Superior medullary velum
item.description: The superior medullary velum is a thin layer of white matter that stretched between the paired superior cerebellar peduncles.  Along with the superior cerebellar peduncles, it forms part of the roof of the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
